Text: @jasonhickel Conclusions from the paper are highly problematic as it 1) asserts eg China and India have no responsibility and indeed are in credit while 2) assigning emissions in In and Cn to the end consumer countries. So there is 0 incentive for Cn and In to regulate their emissions.

@jasonhickel Don't disagree with the overall message but some details are misleading. The paper quoted takes a maximalist approach in trying to blame as much as possible on developed countries. Problems: data back to 1850, ignores forest/LUC, consumption based estimates are dubious

@hilstace @DarienFenton @nzherald It doesn't. That's not how GST works. GST is paid by the end consumer ie the saver. Yes the bank pays GST to its provider BUT it then nets it off the GST it has collected before paying to govt. 

GST is a tax on the consumer, not the service provider. Ie a tax on the saver.
@NigelBrunsdon @nealejones @sublimeligne62 It's a pass through tax to the end consumer. The saver pays.

@Conon6498 @pilcher_pat @nealejones But they pay tax on that as corporate profit tax.

The rate of physiological processes determined by body temperature in these species is temperature-dependent. When the initial temperature is low, the rate of physiological processes increases in a nonlinear pattern as the ambient temperature rises.
#ClimateScience

Climate also has a significant impact on the survival and reproduction of ectotherms, which are creatures that are unable to control their body temperature independently of the temperature of their surroundings. 
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

Climate change may benefit certain species while endangering others. It will have a cumulative effect on biological communities and the functioning of ecosystems.
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

Climate change can disturb the match between organisms and their local environment, lowering survival and reproduction and having an impact on the dispersal of populations or species across geographic regions.
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

Climate has far-reaching consequences for biological systems. Individuals' ability to adapt to local climate patterns determines their chances of survival and reproduction.
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

Even a small tire pile that catches on fire can burn for months before running out of fuel.
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

Just setting tires on the ground for an extended period is enough to eradicate beneficial soil bacteria for nourishment. Without the bacteria, plant and animal species lose habitat and die off.
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

They can then contaminate our lakes and ponds as they leak into groundwater reservoirs.
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

If a tire catches fire, it can spew deadly black smoke. This smoke contains numerous substances. As a result, tire fires cannot be put out with water. The chemicals are wiped away when water is sprayed on this form of fire. 
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

Tires do not degrade. Tires piled up at landfills or junkyards can emit toxins into the air, ground, and water, altering the ecology. A trash tire emits methane gas into the atmosphere by just resting in the sun.
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

Synthetic rubber comes at the cost of one barrel of oil per tire.
#ClimateScience #ClimateActionNow #ClimateEmergency

9/ So how can #IPCC be confident?
1. Advances in #ClimateScience: Number of studies and findings are increasing thus increasing resolution.
2. Advances in #Technology: Given advances in #Computing power, #Supercomputers because to represent earth #Climate needs huge computing.
